Xiamen Key Laboratory of Clean and High-Valued Utilization for Biomass College of Energy Xiamen University Xiamen 361102 China Developing active and affordable catalysts for the transformation of biomass platform into value-added chemicals have drawn tremendous attention. Herein, we have successfully prepared a CoNi bimetallic nitrogen-doped carbon nanotubes (CNTs) catalyst, manifesting outstanding catalytic performance for furfural oxidative esterification under base-free conditions (methyl furoate yield >99%), and great recyclability (5th recycle). Importantly, an impressive methyl furoate formation rate of around 1980 μmolmethyl furoate·gcat −1·h−1 was achieved, to the best of our knowledge, the result represents one of the highest methyl furoate formation rates. The results revealed that the doping of Ni into the CoxNiy-CNTs catalyst brings about more active sites. Fourier transforms infrared spectrometer results suggest that the Ni-Nx sites are responsible for the adsorption of the substrate with tilted or vertical adsorption. Furthermore, the introduction of Ni facilitates the improvement of basicity, which in turn promotes the β-hydride elimination. All of these active sites boost the overall activity of the catalyst for the oxidative esterification of furfural. Graphical abstarct Synopsis: The fabrication of N-doped carbon nanotubes supported CoNi bimetallic catalyst with enhanced O2 activation ability and hydrogen abstraction ability presents excellent activity for base-free oxidative esterification of furfural. Image, graphical abstract Keywords Oxidative esterification Furfural Base-free reaction Nitrogen-doped carbon tube Methyl furoate Data availability The authors are unable or have chosen not to specify which data has been used. 1 Introduction Owing to the increasing demands in energy and the raise of awareness of environmental protection have facilitated the transition away from fossil resources to green alternative renewable resources [1–3]. Biomass as one of the most viable renewable sources for achieving environmentally friendly and sustainable production of bulk chemicals, biofuels, as well as materials has attracted a great deal of attention [4–9]. As one of the top value-added chemicals derived from biomass, furfural is commercially produced from hemicellulose with a production of around 300 kTon/year [10]. With furfural as pivotal platform compounds, a wide range of value-added chemicals have been selectively produced, such as furfuryl alcohol, levulinic acid, γ-valerolactone, maleic acid, and furancarboxylic acid by hydrogenation and oxidation [11–15]. Among, methyl furoate is considered to be an important intermediate of alkyl furoates, which can be applied as a flavor and fragrance component [16]. Hence, growing attention has been paid on the oxidative esterification of furfural to methyl furoate. Generally, the oxidative esterification of furfural into methyl furoate was catalyzed by a homogeneous KMnO4/H2O catalytic system [17,18]. Recently, a series of Pt, Au-based noble metal catalysts have been developed and exhibited higher catalytic efficiency for the oxidative esterification process [16,19–21]. However, the scarcity and high cost of noble metals constitute major barriers to industrial application. Therefore, the development of heterogeneous catalytic systems focused on the non noble-metal is considered an important strategy and attracts tremendous attention. Nitrogen-doped carbon-supported non-noble-metal catalysts have attracted extensive attention due to their promising catalytic activities in the oxygen reduction reaction (ORR), oxygen evolution reaction (OER), as well as oxidative esterification [22–24]. For example, Deng et al. [25] reported a kind of CoxOy–N@C catalysts for the oxidative esterification of hydroxymethylfurfural (HMF) and furfural to prepare corresponding esters, which showed a high yield of 2,5-furandicarboxylic acid methyl (FDMC, 96%) and methyl furoate (95%) in the case of K2CO3 promoters. We have prepared a Co@CN catalyst for the oxidative esterification of HMF and furfural in the presence of base additives. The results demonstrated that the electrons migrater between the metal and N-doping carbon support boosts the excellent catalytic activity for the oxygen activation process [26]. Nevertheless, these reported catalytic systems are less environmentally friendly due to the use of extra-base additives. Recently, N-doped carbon-supported CoCu bimetallic catalysts (CoCu-NC) were prepared in our previous work for the conversion of HMF to afford 96% yield of FDMC under base free conditions [27]. Co-NOPC catalysts were also developed by hard template method for oxidative esterification of furfural, the Co-N was dispersed on a sacrifice template, which showed a 96% methyl furoate selectivity [28]. However, expensive precursors and complicated preparation procedures of these catalysts are considered to be the biggest obstacle to large-scale production. Given these considerations, there is an urgent need to synthesize efficient and low-cost homogeneous nonnoble metal catalysts with a facile method for the oxidative esterification of furfural into methyl furoate. In fact, Co based N-doped carbon nanotube catalysts have been generally acknowledged as the efficient catalyst for catalytic oxidation reactions [29,30]. In this regard, we successfully fabricated a kind of N-doped carbon nanotubes supported CoNi bimetallic catalyst (CoxNiy-CNTs) by a facile drying and calcination technology. Of note, a quantitative furfural conversion (>99%) and methyl furoate yield (>99%) (100 °C, 2 MPa O2, 3 h) was achieved in the case of Co0.8Ni0.2-CNTs under base-free conditions. In this study, the doping of Ni into the CoxNiy-CNTs catalyst brings about more active sites has been well established, and the metallic active species in the catalyst can be controlled via modifying the ratio of Co and Ni precursors. Fourier transform infrared spectrometer results verify that the Ni-Nx sites are responsible for the adsorption of the substrate with tilted or vertical adsorption. In addition, the introduction of Ni also boosts the strong basicity of the catalyst. All of these markedly accelerate the oxygen activation and β-hydride elimination during the oxidative esterification process. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials Furfural (98%), methyl furoate (98%), urea (99%), glucose (99%), Ni(NO3)2·6H2O (99%), Co(NO3)2·6H2O (99%), and other reagents were purchased from Aladdin Chemical Technology Co. Ltd (Shanghai, China). 2.2 Catalyst preparation CoNi bimetallic catalysts with varying Co/Ni ratios were fabricated according to the literature with slight modifications [31]. Typically procedure, glucose (100 mg) and urea (8 equivalent relatives to metal nitrates) were well-dispersed in 70 mL of deionized water. Co and Ni nitrates solution with different molar ratios was then added dropwise to the solution with vigorous stirring. Sequentially, a precursor mixture was obtained after evaporation at 80 °C. Then, the precursor mixture was subjected to calcination at 800 °C for 4 h under an N2 atmosphere, thereby generating the CoxNiy-CNTs catalyst (x/y = 0.9/0.1, 0.8/0.2, 0.5/0.5, 0.4/0.6, 0.2/0.8, in which x/y denotes the molar ratio of Co/Ni in the catalyst). Co-CNTs and Ni-CNTs could be prepared by the same method. 2.3 Catalyst characterization The catalyst was characterized by scanning electron microscopy (SEM), X-ray diffraction (XRD), Transmission electron microscopy (TEM), Fourier transform infrared spectrometer (FTIR), Raman spectra, X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), O2 temperature-programmed oxidation (O2-TPO), O2 temperature-programmed desorption (O2-TPD), and CO2-TPD, in which the details were presented in the Supporting Information. 2.4 Oxidative esterification of furfural to methyl furoate Typically, furfural (0.3 mmol), catalyst (0.05 g), and methanol (3 mL) were loaded into the autoclave. Afterward, the reaction mixture was carried out under 2 MPa O2 at 120 °C for 3 h with stirring (600 rpm). After the reaction, the used catalyst was recovered by centrifugation and washed with methanol before being dried at 100 °C for 12 h. Liquid products were analyzed by GC-mass spectrometry (GC–MS) and GC analysis. The details are listed in Supporting Information. Conversion, products yield, carbon balance, initial reaction rates, and methyl furoate formation rate were calculated according to the following eqs: C furfural ( % ) = ( 1 − mol of furfural in the products initial mol of furfural ) × 100 Y X ( % ) = mol of X in the products initial mol of furfural × 100 Carbon balance ( % ) = ∑ mols of C in products mols of C in furfural converted × 100 Initial reaction rate ( μ mol · g Cat − 1 · mi n − 1 ) = mol of furfural converted catalyst loading × reaction time × 100 Methyl furoate formation rate ( μ mo l methyl furoate · g Cat − 1 · mi n − 1 ) = mol of methyl furoate catalyst loading × reaction time 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalyst preparation and characterization As demonstrated in Fig. 1 a, the CoxNiy-CNTs can be simply fabricated through drying and calcination of the precursor mixture. Glucose and urea are introduced as carbon carriers and nitrogen sources, respectively. The catalyst with different metals content can be accurately controlled by adjusting the ratio of Co and Ni nitrates precursors. As shown in the SEM image (Fig. S1), the sole metal Co-CNTs catalyst with a markedly 3D network carbon nanotube structure, which comes from the catalysis of the Co atom [32]. However, the carbon nanotube structure disappeared with the increase of Ni comments. It can be seen that when the ratio of Co:Ni changed from 8:2 to 4:6, the carbon nanotube structure distinctly decreased, forming the composite structures of carbon nanotube and N-doped carbon bulk, resulting in a markedly lower BET surface area. Meanwhile, the catalytic experiments results revealed that Co0.4Ni0.6-CNTs achieved a much lower yield than that of the Co0.8Ni0.2-CNTs, which with a markedly 3D network carbon nanotube structure. Thus, it can be concluded that the support CNTs showed better catalytic performance. It can be ascribed to the 3D network structure CNTs containing micropores, mesopores, and macropores structures, which in turn the larger specific surface area of the catalyst, conduciving to expose more active sites interact with oxygen and facilitating the mass transfer during the reaction process. Moreover, SEM analysis shows that there are many Co species inside the sole metal Co-CNTs, proper doping of Ni facilitates the inside Co species migration to the surface of the CNTs carrier, thereby favorable for more metal active site exposure without the aggregation of metal nanoparticles (NPs). TEM and element mapping images of Co0.8Ni0.2-CNTs (Figs. 1b, f-g, and S2) exhibit that Ni and Co NPs are highly dispersed on the CNTs with an average particle size of 27.5 nm. High-resolution TEM (HR-TEM) (Fig. 1c) demonstrated the legible lattice fringe spacing of 0.205 nm, corresponding to the (111) plane of the Co metallic NPs, respectively, and the lattice fringe with a spacing of 0.34 nm attributed to the graphitic carbon [33,34]. The (111) and (220) planes of the Co NPs were also identified by the HR-TEM image of the selected area (Fig. 1d). Apparently, the Co metallic NPs were encapsulated by N-doped CNTs, thus dampening the aggregation of metallic atoms. The crystalline nature of the carbon catalysts is further characterized by XRD (Fig. 2 ). As for Ni-CNTs, the peak at about 44.5°, 51.8°, and 76.4° correspond to metallic Ni (JCPDS 87-0712) [35]. With the incorporation of Co into Ni-CNTs, downshifts of the diffraction peaks of CoxNiy-CNTs were observed. For Co0.5Ni0.5-CNTs with similar Co-Ni contents, the feature peaks at 44.3°, 51.6°, and 76.0° are attributed to the (111), (200), and (220) planes of the CoNi alloy [36,37], indicating the generation of the CoNi alloy phase. Interestingly, with further improving the ratio of Co (≥ 0.8), diffraction peaks shifted to a lower range, which matches well with the characteristic peaks of metallic Co at 44.2°, 51.5°, and 75.8° (JCPDS 89-7093) [38]. These results reveal that the metallic species in the catalyst can be controlled via modifying the ratio of Co and Ni precursors. Among, Co0.8Ni0.2-CNTs possesses the diffraction peaks of metallic Co, and there is no diffractive peak of metallic Ni phase, which was in accordance with the TEM results. Especially, it exhibited a distinctly lower diffraction intensity, suggesting both the dispersity of Ni and Co were improved after an appropriate amount of Co was introduced into Ni-CNTs, probably due to the interaction between Ni and Co. The pore structure information was investigated through N2 adsorption-desorption analysis. As shown in Table 1 , Figs. S3, and S4, the increase of Co content in the catalyst gaves rise to high surface area (SBET), large pore volume (Vpore) and plentiful mesopores, which can provide efficient channels for mass transport [39,40]. However, smaller SBET, Vpore, and pore diameter were observed to further enhance the ratio of Co, it can be concluded from the weakening of the interaction between Ni and Co with the decrease in Ni content. Generally, the reaction happens only on the catalyst surface, herein, the surface composition of CoxNiy-CNTs catalysts was further confirmed by XPS analysis to represent the upper limits of the actual amount of active sites (Table 1). The surface metal concentration was approximately 2.5 wt% for all CoxNiy-CNTs catalysts. Of note, the bimetallic catalyst with high Co/Ni ratio possesses a higher N amount than monometallic Ni and Co catalysts, and Co0.8Ni0.2-CNTs had the highest N contents (6.6%) among these CoxNiy-CNTs catalysts. Raman spectra were then carried out to investigate the structural defects in the CNTs. As shown in Fig. 3 , the peaks at about 1340 and 1590 cm-1 corresponds to the defective disordered carbon (D band) and crystalline graphite carbon (G band) [32,41], respectively. The bimetallic CNTs proved higher ID/IG band intensity ratios than monometallic Co-CNTs and Ni-CNTs. Especially, Co0.8Ni0.2-CNTs has the highest ID/IG ratios of 1.04, revealing that there were more defect sites over bimetallic Co0.8Ni0.2-CNTs as compared with the others [42]. 3.2 Oxidative esterification of furfural over various CoxNiy-CNTs catalysts The catalytic performances of as-prepared catalysts were evaluated for aerobic oxidative esterification of furfural under base-free conditions, the exploratory catalytic experiments results were summarized in Table 2 . Co-CNTs catalyst exhibits moderate conversion of furfural (75%) and 67% yield of methyl furoate (Table 2, entry 9), whereas the use of the Ni-CNTs catalyst led to a low methyl furoate yield of 11% (Table 2, entry 1), demonstrating Co species are responsible for this oxidative esterification. Moreover, the catalytic activity of Co0.9Ni0.1-CNTs has obvious efficiency improvement with the introduction of nickel, and 97% furfural conversion and 94% yield of methyl furoate were achieved (Table 2, entry 8). Of note, a quantitative furfural conversion (>99%) and methyl furoate yield (>99%) were achieved in the case of Co0.8Ni0.2-CNTs (Table 2, entry 7). However, further increasing the proportion of Ni in Co0.7Ni0.3-CNTs leads to a lower catalytic efficiency with 90% furfural conversion and 87% methyl furoate yield under identical reaction conditions (Table 2, entry 6). It should be noticed that the catalytic activity of CoxNiy-CNTs catalysts is in line with the N content in the preparation of CoxNiy-CNTs (Tables 1 and 2). In accordance with the literature [38,43,44,45], Co-Nx species on N-doped carbon grants catalytic activity for the oxidative esterification of aldehydes and/or alcohols. In this regard, it is rational that Co0.8Ni0.2-CNTs might offer more active Co-Nx species because of their highest N content, thus disclosing an excellent catalytic efficiency. The kinetic curves (Fig. 4 a) present that furoic acid (FA) was formed as an intermediate and a superior yield of methyl furoate (>99%) was achieved with almost complete conversion of furfural at 100 °C for 3 h without base additive. Particularly, Co0.8Ni0.2-CNTs catalyst could afford an impressive methyl furoate formation rate of around 1980 μmolmethyl furoate·gcat −1·h−1 and furfural initial reaction rate of 380 μmol·gcat −1·h−1 under optimum conditions. To the best of our knowledge, the result represents one of the highest methyl furoate formation rates, rivaling many reported non-noble and precious catalysts (Table 2, entries 10–16) [16,25,43,46,47]. More importantly, compared with the reported Co-based catalysts, as-synthesized Co0.8Ni0.2-CNTs could provide an exciting formation rate under base-free conditions, while a relative lower formation rates of reported catalysts (67–1584 μmolmethyl furoate·gcat −1·h−1) was achieved in involvement of base additive (Table 2, entries 12–14) [25]. Additionally, the recyclability of the Co0.8Ni0.2-CNTs catalyst was investigated and the results are displayed in Fig. 4b. It is found that the yield of methyl furoate decreased slightly with the 5th cycle, namely the Co0.8Ni0.2-CNTs exhibited benign cyclability in oxidative esterification. The structure and morphology of spent Co0.8Ni0.2-CNTs were further observed by XRD (Fig. S5) and SEM (Fig. S6). The overall structural integrity and morphology of the used Co0.8Ni0.2-CNTs were kept nearly unchanged compared with the fresh one. On the other hand, the FTIR (Fig. S7) results indicated that the absorption peak strength of the 5th recovered Co0.8Ni0.2-CNTs catalyst decreased. It can be mainly attributed to the leached of active specie as well as the surface carbon depositions on Co0.8Ni0.2-CNTs catalyst. To further investigate the stability of Co0.8Ni0.2-CNTs, the leaching test was conducted after a 0.5 h reaction. No further conversion of furfural was detected even extended reaction time to 4 h (Fig. 4a), indicating that the metal active specie did not leach into the reaction liquid. Fortunately, the slightly-deactivated catalyst could be simply regenerated by calcined at 400 °C for 1 h under an N2 atmosphere, and the methyl furoate yield was resumed as before (Fig. 4b). Thus it can be inferred that the deactivation of the catalyst is owing to the carbon deposition on catalyst surface. These results evidently confirm that the Co0.8Ni0.2-CNTs catalyst exhibits great cycling durability. 3.3 Catalytic mechanism Usually, the catalytic activity of the catalyst is sensitive to its surface physicochemical properties, thus, the surface structures and adsorption behavior of the catalyst were further performed to obtain insight into the catalytic mechanism. The surface structure and chemical valence state of the elements was examined by XPS. The N 1s spectra of CoxNiy-CNTs are deconvoluted into three peaks at about 398.4, 399.9, and 400.9 eV, which is attributed to pyridinic N, pyrrolic N, and graphitic N (Fig. 5 a and Table S2) [48]. The results showed the ratio of pyridinic N increased with increasing Ni amount in CoxNiy-CNTs, Co0.8Ni0.2-CNTs offers the most abundant pyridinic N amount, while the further increase of Ni amount decreases the pyridinic N content. The Ni 2p peak of CoxNiy-CNTs centered at around 854.7 and 872.2 eV (Fig. 5b and Table S3), which are attributed to Ni-O or Ni-Nx species [49]. However, an O 1 s peak at 532.0 eV is attributed to absorbed oxygen (Fig. S8) and no peak for nickel oxide was found in the XRD pattern of CoxNiy-CNTs (Fig. 2), excluding the possible species of Ni–Ox bonds. That is to say, Ni mainly interacted with the N atoms to generate Ni-Nx species. The Co 2p spectra of CoxNiy-CNTs verify the presence of Co0 (779.0 eV) and Co-Nx (780.6 eV), respectively (Table S4). Apparently, as presented in Fig. 5c, the relative ratio of Co-Nx species progressively increased with the introduction of Ni from 71.3% in Co-CNTs to 84.5% in Co0.8Ni0.2-CNTs, then declines to 70.9% in Co0.4Ni0.6-CNTs. It has been extensively documented that the Co-Nx species are responsible for the oxidative esterification of aldehydes and/or alcohols [38,43,44,45], thus it is understandable that Co0.8Ni0.2-CNTs demonstrates the optimal catalytic activity for the transformation of furfural (Table 2). Furthermore, a good linear relationship between the pyridinic N amount and Co-Nx species content was observed (Tables S2 and S4), which is owing to the pyridinic N being responsible for the formation of metal-nitrogen sites [24,50]. On the other hand, the binding energy of the Co-Nx sites shifts to a lower value in the bimetallic CoxNiy-CNTs (around 780.6 eV) from 781.1 eV in sole Co-CNTs (Fig. 5c, Table S4). Whereas the binding energy of Ni 2p up-shifted to a higher range in the bimetallic CoxNiy-CNTs compared with that of sole Ni-CNTs (from 854.4 to 850.0 eV and 871.6 to 872.3 eV) (Fig. 5b, Table S3). The redshifts disclose the electron migration tendency from Ni to Co in CoxNiy-CNTs [27]. It has been previously reported that the activation of molecular oxygen could be achieved by gaining electron from the metal-Nx sites [31], and the activation of molecular oxygen to reactive oxygen species (superoxide radicals, •O2 −) play a crucial role during the aerobic oxidation [51]. The result indicated that the introduction of Ni into CoxNiy-CNTs probably contributed to the O2 activation ability of CoxNiy-CNTs catalyst. To further confirm the active sites of CoxNiy-CNTs for O2 adsorption, O2-TPO and O2-TPD were carried out. As presented in Fig. 5d, Ni-CNTs exhibited an O2-TPO peak at 656 °C, which is attributed to the strong chemically adsorbed oxygen [52]. Compared to Ni-CNTs catalyst, Co-based catalysts exhibited stronger oxygen adsorption ability after introducing Co active species. A strong peak centered at 726 °C appeared in the spectrum of Co-CNTs. It is widely acknowledged that O2 could be activated by the metal-Nx sites [26,43], it can also be assumed that Co-Nx sites played a vital role in O2 adsorption and activation. In addition, O2-TPD of Ni-CNTs and Co-CNTs catalysts was also conducted and a similar conclusion was observed relative to that of O2-TPO. As shown in Fig. 5e, both of Ni-CNTs and Co-CNTs exhibited one oxidation peak at the range of 300–550 °C, which corresponded to strong chemically adsorbed oxygen. Whereas no significant physically adsorbed oxygen (< 300 °C) and lattice oxygen (> 500 °C) characteristic peaks were observed [53]. Compared to the small peaks for Ni-CNTs, the obvious oxidation peaks for Co-CNTs further demonstrated the better O2 adsorption ability of Co-Nx sites. Building on the above results, it is beyond doubt that Ni-doping facilitates the electron intensity around Co in Co-Nx sites to improve the O2 activation ability of Co-Nx sites, thus accelerating the generation of oxygen radicals. Additionally, one should note that the enrichment in the amount of pyridinic N is believed to provide more and stronger basic sites derives from their lone pair of electrons [43,54]. Herein, the basic sites of the catalysts were directly monitored by CO2-TPD. As evidenced in Fig. 5f, the peaks at 332 and 408 °C signified Ni-CNTs possessed medium−strong base sites. With the improvement of the Co ratio in the catalyst, the more significant CO2 desorption peak with higher desorption temperature was observed. Especially, Co0.8Ni0.2-CNTs presented strong basic sites with the highest density, demonstrating that Co0.8Ni0.2-CNTs possessed a high concentration of strong base sites. Generally, the improvement of the surface basicity of the catalyst favored the hydrogen abstraction process [55–57], thereby boosting the catalytic activity for furfural oxidative esterification in the absence of a base additive. To further investigate the adsorption behavior of furfural over the catalyst, FTIR was employed to monitor the interaction of furfural and CoxNiy-CNTs at the molecular level. Co-CNTs and Ni-CNTs were employed to represent the Co-Nx and Ni-Nx species in CoxNiy-CNTs, respectively. As presented in Fig. 6 a, After the saturated adsorption of furfural with Ni-CNTs, characteristic peaks of the furan ring remain unchanged, while the peak of furfural C1=O1 band at 1671 cm-1 drift to a low wavenumber of 1631 cm-1 [58]. This may be due to the C1=O1 in furfural adsorpted on the Ni-Nx sites of the Ni-CNTs by O-terminal adsorption. On the contrary, in addition to the slight shift of the C1=O1 peak, the furan ring characteristic peak shifted significantly to the lower region (from 747 to 670 cm-1) after the saturated adsorption of furfural on the surface of Co-Nx sites enriched Co-CNTs (Fig. 6b). It proved the strong interaction between the furan ring and Co-CNTs, along with O-terminal adsorption of the aldehyde group of furfural on Co-Nx sites. That is to say, furfural is absorbed on the Ni-Nx sites of Ni-CNTs with O-terminal adsorption of the C1=O1 bond (Fig. 6d), while a flat configuration of furfural over the Co-Nx sites of Co-CNTs (Fig. 6e). Subsequently, as Co0.8Ni0.2-CNTs/furfural (Fig. 6c), the redshift occurs in the C1=O1 bond (from 1671 to 1632 cm-1), which is ascribed to the O-terminal adsorption of the aldehyde group in furfural on the surface of Co0.8Ni0.2-CNTs. The characteristic peaks of the furan ring are unchanged. As previously reported, a stronger chemisorption was observed between the aldehyde group of furan derivatives and electron-poor metal sites, while the furan ring is mainly adsorbed by the metal-Nx sites with abundant electron density [31,43,59]. It can thus infer that the Ni-Nx sites in Co0.8Ni0.2-CNTs are mainly responsible for the adsorption of furfural. Of note, as indicated in the oxidative esterification result of furfural over Co0.8Ni0.2-CNTs (Table 2, entry 7), an outstanding selectivity (99%) of methyl furoate was achieved. indicating that the furan ring of furfural was hardly affected. These results verify that a tilted or vertical adsorption between the O-terminal of the aldehyde group and the Ni-Nx sites, with a furan ring away the catalyst surface (Fig. 6f). The above observations well demonstrated the introduction of Ni into CoxNiy-CNTs endowed the catalysts possessed abundant metal-Nx sites (i.e. Co-Nx and Ni-Nx sites) and a high concentration of strong base sites. The Co-Nx sites functioned to improve the adsorption and activation of oxygen, and the Ni-Nx sites are responsible for furfural adsorbed on the catalyst surface with tilted or vertical adsorption. In addition, the strong basic sites can promote hydrogen abstraction. The synergy of Co-Nx, Ni-Nx sites, and strong base sites boosts the improvement of the catalytic activity for the oxidative esterification of furfural under base-free conditions. Based on the results mentioned above, the catalytic mechanism for the oxidative esterification of furfural to methyl furoate over Co0.8Ni0.2-CNTs has been summarized in Scheme 1 . Firstly, the molecule oxygen is adsorbed and activated by the Co-Nx to generate •O2 − radicals. Then the •O2 − radicals attack the methanol resulting in the formation of a methoxy. Meanwhile, the aldehyde group in furfural is adsorbed on the electron-poor Ni-Nx sites via O-terminal adsorption with tilted or vertical adsorption. Following this, the Co-Nx species promotes the activation of the aldehyde group and accelerates the formation of hemiacetal between furfural and methoxy. Finally, the basic sites facilitate the β-hydride elimination of the hemiacetal intermediate to methyl furoate. Simultaneously, the regeneration of the active metal surface can be achieved over the basic sites by boosting the deprotonation of the H-metal species, which are commonly generated during the β-hydride elimination process [43]. 4 Conclusions In this contribution, we have demonstrated an effective and recyclable Co0.8Ni0.2-CNTs catalyst for the base-free oxidative esterification of furfural to methyl furoate, offering satisfactory furfural conversion (>99%), methyl furoate yield (>99%). Importantly, an impressive methyl furoate formation rate of around 1980 μmolmethyl furoate·gcat −1·h−1 was achieved, to the best of our knowledge, the result represents one of the highest methyl furoate formation rates. The results revealed the doping of Ni into the CoxNiy-CNTs catalyst in favor of the enhancement of active site amount. The FTIR investigation reveals the Ni-Nx sites contribute to the adsorption of furfural with tilted or vertical adsorption. In addition, the introduction of Ni into the CoxNiy-CNTs affords a high concentration of strong base sites, which is conducive to the β-hydride elimination during the oxidative esterification of furfural under base-free conditions. The cooperation of these active sites is responsible for the overall activity of the oxidative esterification process. The development of this bimetal CoNi carbon nanotube provides a viable strategy for the design of bimetal-nitrogen-carbon materials with cooperative active centers for oxidation reactions. coredata.dc:description: Developing active and affordable catalysts for the transformation of biomass platform into value-added chemicals have drawn tremendous attention. Herein, we have successfully prepared a CoNi bimetallic nitrogen-doped carbon nanotubes (CNTs) catalyst, manifesting outstanding catalytic performance for furfural oxidative esterification under base-free conditions (methyl furoate yield >99%), and great recyclability (5th recycle). Importantly, an impressive methyl furoate formation rate of around 1980 μmolmethyl furoate·gcat −1·h−1 was achieved, to the best of our knowledge, the result represents one of the highest methyl furoate formation rates. The results revealed that the doping of Ni into the CoxNiy-CNTs catalyst brings about more active sites. Fourier transforms infrared spectrometer results suggest that the Ni-Nx sites are responsible for the adsorption of the substrate with tilted or vertical adsorption. Furthermore, the introduction of Ni facilitates the improvement of basicity, which in turn promotes the β-hydride elimination. All of these active sites boost the overall activity of the catalyst for the oxidative esterification of furfural.
coredata.dc:title: Insight into the catalytic mechanism of N-doped carbon nanotubes supported CoNi bimetallic catalyst boosts the base-free oxidative esterification of furfural
